title: 108_s120
content: The "Marriage Penalty Relief Act of 2003" is also known as the Act. It accelerates the provisions for relief from marriage penalties. The Marriage Penalty Relief Act of 2003 accelerates relief from marriage penalties by eliminating the marriage penalty in the standard deduction under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Marriage Penalty Relief Act of 2003 eliminates the marriage penalty in the standard deduction under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. The Marriage Penalty Relief Act of 2003 eliminates the marriage penalty in the 15-percent tax bracket for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. The Marriage Penalty Relief Act of 2003 eliminates the marriage penalty in the 15-percent tax bracket for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. Technical amendments are made to the tax code regarding taxable income amounts and rounding. The Marriage Penalty Relief Act of 2003 eliminates the marriage penalty in the 15-percent tax bracket for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. Amendments are made to the tax code regarding earned income credit phaseout amounts. The Marriage Penalty Relief Act of 2003 eliminates the marriage penalty in the 15-percent tax bracket for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. Amendments are made to the tax code regarding earned income credit phaseout amounts. The amendments include an expansion of mathematical error authority related to claiming the child tax credit under section 32. The amendment to the Federal Case Registry of Child Support Orders under the Social Security Act identifies the taxpayer as a noncustodial parent. The effective date of this amendment is January 1, 2003. Conforming amendments repeal certain sections of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001.
